hypothesis: Structural features (EAD completeness, backward lesson refs, domain, DOMEX provenance) predict whether an experiment gets cited by a lesson. Target: >70% classification accuracy.
method: Scanned 561 experiment JSONs across all domains. Extracted 11 boolean features + 4 continuous features. Computed conversion rates per feature, domain, session era, file size. Built rule-based classifier.

classifier.rule: candidate_lesson_id OR (EAD>=2 AND cites_lessons) OR (DOMEX AND verdict)

expect: Experiment features predict conversion with >70% accuracy. Top predictor identified.
actual: Accuracy 78.1% (below 85.7% naive baseline), F1=0.289. Top predictor by lift: has_candidate_lesson (5.26x, n=4 only). Top by sample: has_measurements (2.67x, n=21), outcome_clear (2.25x, n=53). Session era dominates all features: S0-S186=5.6% vs S187+=27.0% (4.8x gap). EAD=3 converts at 31.9% (2.24x). File size non-monotonic: Q2 (1.7-3K) best at 22%, Q4 (>8K) drops to 10%.
diff: Predicted >70% accuracy — got 78.1% but BELOW naive baseline (class imbalance makes accuracy misleading). Predicted features discriminate — CONFIRMED (lifts 1.5-5.3x) but insufficient for prediction. Did NOT predict era dominance: the S0-S186 / S187+ split explains more variance than any structural feature. The '85% loss rate' is a Simpson's paradox from mixed populations.
verdict: PARTIALLY CONFIRMED. Features discriminate (lifts 1.5-5.3x) but don't classify (F1=0.29). The real finding is Simpson's paradox: legacy tail (51% of experiments, 5.6% conversion) dominates the measured rate. Modern pipeline converts at 27%. L-678.
key_finding: Session era is the primary predictor of experiment-to-lesson conversion. EAD enforcement (S331) created a structural regime change. The '85% loss' metric conflates two populations with 4.8x different base rates.
next_steps: Selective harvest of S0-S186 experiments with measurements or clear outcomes (est. 40-50 candidates)
Backward edge patching: update old experiment JSONs to cite lessons that reference them
Track modern-pipeline conversion rate (27%) as separate KPI from system-wide rate
Test whether 27% is near-ceiling by comparing DOMEX vs non-DOMEX within S187+
